descriptionSet.description: On this advertisement for Brooke Bond Tea, a village celebration with traditional Indian musical instruments and people dressed in village garb, has a giant box of Brooke Bond tea as the centre of attraction and perhaps the reason for the celebration. The women and men are dancing around it as a man holds it aloft. Some of the dancers also hold cups of tea in their hand and there is a tea service and a box of tea on the ground nearby too. The image of a traditionally dressed Indian woman and her baby is on the box of tea. In the background, some plants and bushes can be seen. The tagline of the advertisement is written in English, Hindi and Bengali and so perhaps directed to the Bengali segment.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: Brooke Bond Tea
text-hi: दिलचस्पौ का केन्द्र । ("कोरा डस्ट")
text-en: Kora Dust
text-bn: ADD TEXT HERE
text-en: The Centre of Attraction! ("Kora Dust")
text-hi: Dilchaspon ka kendra ("Kora Dust")

description-en: On this advertisement for Brooke Bond Tea, a village celebration with traditional Indian musical instruments and people dressed in village garb, has a giant box of Brooke Bond tea as the centre of attraction and perhaps the reason for the celebration. The women and men are dancing around it as a man holds it aloft. Some of the dancers also hold cups of tea in their hand and there is a tea service and a box of tea on the ground nearby too. The image of a traditionally dressed Indian woman and her baby is on the box of tea. In the background, some plants and bushes can be seen. The tagline of the advertisement is written in English, Hindi and Bengali and so perhaps directed to the Bengali segment. (sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Although full-leaf Darjeeling and Assam tea remained a comparatively expensive commodity, and most pre-Independence advertising was aimed at a middle class audience, cheaper grades of "dust" and "fannings" (fragments of leaves that were a by-product of tea processing) also began to be marketed. An example is Brooke Bond's "Kora Dust," placed in this image in the context of a rural "folk" festival featuring musicians, dancers, and (improbably) the company's prominently displayed packaging, with a logo featuring the Madonna and Child. Such "crude" blends were often issued in small packets, displayed in perforated chains (mālās or "garlands") and sold for "one ānā" (one-sixteenth of a rupee) in small dry-goods shops. These packets were also sometimes distributed as free samples by bicycle-riding promoters employed by tea blending companies, who visited small towns and villages. (Philip Lutgendorf) (gs)
